body:
> Side question. There seems to be at least two method to evolving PRs.
> 
> 1. Multiple commits with squash when merged
> 2. Use force and keep it a single commit
> 
> Is 1. easier to work with (considering the current situation). They should give the same result, right?

@errael side answer ðŸ˜„  please don't squash and merge. Both GitHub UI and CLI have (different) negative side effects there. Do agree that multiple commits can be better when kept during reviews though. PR branches are generally writable by committers as well as authors, so squashing and force pushing into the PR branch (where warranted) for final checks before merging is ideal IMO.

> (force pushes can be reviewed via the delta on github, so it is usually no problem as long the delta is small)

Yeah, "Compare" is one of my favorite buttons.

To be clear: as evidenced by the compare buttons the changes made by the last forced push are known (at least to github). Is there a way to back up to a particular spot? 

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/2d816721023a7e00d7fb3cc83f9347f90f834157
![GoodBase](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20450427/216795604-74f7aef0-1cc9-413e-b525-ab17708ca242.png)

was pretty clean

It had a few more changes than expected, but they were in line with the goal of this PR and looked OK. Only dealt with `HashSet` --> `EnumSet`

There were a small handful of items that drew my attention including a few things that got lost from the previous change.
Any progress here? Will this ever be a thing? Or is there some way how to open project on linux in Netbeans in Windows?
FIXED

@mokraemer please have a look at the referenced PR and test it. If you need a prebuild binary, it is available from the CI summary or from this direct link: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/suites/10786014570/artifacts/542201388

@noelma  please have a look at the referenced PR and test it. If you need a prebuild binary, it is available from the CI summary or from this direct link: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/suites/10786014570/artifacts/542201388

downloaded the referenced dev build.
It looks good for me. No more complains about the syntax.

Thanks!
cc/ @junichi11 any thoughts on this? Is the plugin in a state that it could be delivered by plugin centre?

It was unclear how I should propose a "prototype" for discussion. So I recreated a discussion about it and submitted this pull request to help. It's not my intention to have this integrated.

If I didn't follow protocol, then just let me know. Also, if there is a better process, then also, please, let me know.
If this affects NetBeans development I think it belongs onto ` dev@`. I don't read discussions and I'm pretty sure I'm not the only developer.
I have no doubt we need to address the end of finalization, but I'm not sure we need to be changing the base release version of modules just to add the extended variety of the deprecated annotation?!

> I have no doubt we need to address the end of finalization, but I'm not sure we need to be changing the base release version of modules just to add the extended variety of the deprecated annotation?!

Hey @neilcsmith-net , I mostly agree with your comments.

Here's the problem.

We are going to need to change the base release if and when we resolve the finalization issue. That much we all agree on. I'm simply proposing that we start the process to make the work easier later on.

The first step in that process, to me, would be to mark the `finalize()` methods as deprecated like I propose. Doing this makes the process a little bit "easier" because the spots that need work will be more easily discoverable.

> We are going to need to change the base release if and when we resolve the finalization issue.

You can replace `finalize()` using JDK 8 if need be.  Admittedly not if we decide to use JDK Cleaner API, but that's not the only option.

We haven't yet agree to move the platform beyond JDK 8.  Some of these should upgrade to JDK 11 when we're ready to move the platform as a whole.  At least `o.n.bootstrap` will need to wait for that.
@vieiro thank you for the review. I pushed updates - could you have another look?

we should track this as issue.
we have one for ThreadDeath: #4952
and one umbrella issue for all JDK 11 incompatible tests: #4904

added #5440 for the finalization mechaninsm

Hello again,

the Kotlin editor (using TextMate language support) can be found here
<https://github.com/apache/netbeans/tree/kotlin-donation/java/kotlin.editor>.
The JetBrains contribution (JavaCC) can be found here
<https://github.com/apache/netbeans/tree/kotlin-donation/contrib/kotlin>. I
will push my progress to my personal git repo in order not to pollute the
NetBeans repo.

Thanks.

John.

follow the JetBrains' guys advice and update my local maven repo with the
dependencies from the kotlin-eclipse plugin (see this thread
<https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1398>) as I don't see and local
commits or changed files from my side.

plugin.

I would propose to use the #plugin-developers slack channel to provide
support to those who wish to help resolve these issues on how to build the
java part and then concentrate on the kotlin part.

Kind regards,

John.

Before https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5309#pullrequestreview-1284110254 comment, I reviewed the PR and updates pretty carefully. After this comment, along with a little cleanup, the singleton/emptySet stuff happened. I checked this PR, ignoring the emptySet/singleton changes.

Then the change to get rid of the emptySet/singleton changes. I reviewed this change to insure that only singleton/emptySet stuff was changed. In addition to those changes, _did find around 5 more changes for HashSet --> EnumSet_, sigh. @tbw777, it's not unusual for there to be follow on PRs to clean up a few things, missed or otherwise, in a large PR as needed, rather than modifying a huge PR.

Now to verify that all the singleton/emptySet were reverted.

Pulled the PR, generated a diff, grep'd for "singleton" and "emptySet". Did not find any changes that included them (other than some white space).

So the commit looks OK to me. But I didn't start from scratch; another set of eyes...

(did find some unneeded changes, but I'm hesitant to point them out)

> Pulled the PR, generated a diff, grep'd for "singleton" and "emptySet". Did not find any changes that included them (other than some white space).

@errael here a trick (but don't tell anyone): just add .diff or .patch to get a diff/patch file
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5309.diff
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5309.patch

1) To explain the focus adjustment thing a bit more: If you select e.g. a Java method in the Navigator, then the tree component gets focus. But if you then press tab a few times, you see that the focus indication "disappears" a few times during the focus cycle, due to components that are marked as focusable but which don't actually handle keyboard focus in any way. It's the child components of the NavigatorTC that should receive focus, but not the NavigatorTC itself (except when the Navigator is in the empty state, as alluded to in an earlier comment).

2) Sure, here's a before/after screenshot of the Connection Properties dialog:

![gridlines](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/886243/216862443-4748ff15-bc41-4187-9c7a-6b32d5008939.png)

(The grid lines are rather light, but omitting them completely makes the dialog quite hard to understand.)

> a trick (but don't tell anyone): just add .diff or .patch to get a diff/patch file

No matter how hard I try, I keep learning things about github. Thanks ;-)

> @errael side answer smile please don't squash and merge. Both GitHub UI and CLI have (different) negative side effects there. Do agree that multiple commits can be better when kept during reviews though. PR branches are generally writable by committers as well as authors, so squashing and force pushing into the PR branch (where warranted) for final checks before merging is ideal IMO.

@neilcsmith-net I had always thought that references to `CLI` were about the `git` command. But I couldn't deny my ignorance anymore after reading what you said, yet another thing about git/github I didn't want to know.

So if I get this right, a pattern is to push several commits to a PR, then after approval, can squash locally (using mercurial in my case) and force push to the PR.

Does the compare button associated with a forced push after a local-squash/force-push show no changes (assuming, of course, that there were no changes)?

> Is the plugin in a state that it could be delivered by plugin centre?

No. I'll add it to the PP when I have time.

> @neilcsmith-net I had always thought that references to `CLI` were about the `git` command.

@errael in that context it did! Any local squash and merge pushed directly to master causes its own set of issues. Gone a bit off topic! Can follow that up on dev@ if more info needed.

There are two approvals, and someone wearing a release manager's hat said "Let's stick with what you have and see if any complaints come out of the woodwork!". I'll count that as 2+ approvals, no negatives.

@mbien @sdedic (or @neilcsmith-net wearing a different hat) any further comments?

Can this get merged?

BTW, I think this PR will take care of several items I listed in #4887, I'll go through them all and see if they meet the criteria covered by this PR. The big revelation for me is that the layout decisions happen mostly in NbPresenter (with an occasional assist from openide.util.Utilities). I'll patch NB-17 release with this PR and keep my eyes open for follow on issues (I haven't been using NB lately).

@matthiasblaesing @mbien I'm willing to consider the problem (not related to this PR) both of you can reproduce (and I can't).

I think info gathered from `NbPresenter` as mentioned in https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5280#issuecomment-1382314612 might be important in understanding what's going on.

There was some thought that it might be an issue with `DialogDisplayer` as mentioned in https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5280#pullrequestreview-1252234566 but my guess is not.

And https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5280#issuecomment-1397371539 might help in understanding what's going on.

If you want/can open up a bug with some info (especially reproducability) I'd like to know about it.
Lets get this in.
this has been likely fixed in NB 17. Would be good to verify.
no further comments, all green. merging. (removed old change request since it got [resolved](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5309#issuecomment-1399397415) a while ago)
@pepness I just merged a larger cleanup PR which caused conflicts here. Should be hopefully easy to resolve - bad timing sorry about that.

* `@deprecated` javadoc tag is there to provide migration guidance for the API user - if the message is empty it serves no purpose.
* `@Deprecated` annotation is sufficient to make it show up as deprecated in the javadoc and produce a compiler warning

This means having an empty javadoc tag serves no purpose, it should be only added to provide a meaningful message.

I looked through this and I believe this should be fine @neilcsmith-net. A lot of this are language identifier comparisons, file endings, SQL queries etc. Whenever there is a comparison with a constant like "dev" it shouldn't matter if the cases are compared with a specific local or not.

The only area I am not 100% sure about is the bugzilla package - maybe you could take a look at this one. If you aren't sure either we can skip it.
You are right

@pepness 

> Use switch expression

You mean replace if -> switch, not SE introduced in jvm14 ))
I think if/else more safe because you cant lost a "break" and no "default" case needed.

> Add missing Override annotations

#5203 ALL CASES, OPENED

>Use diamond inference on declaration-initialization

#5414 REJECTED, CLOSED
#5214 REJECTED, CLOSED

>Use try-with-resources

#5328 MOST CASES/ALL, OPENED

>Use lambdas when possible

In most cases equal lambdas are more slowly

>Use generics

Changing interfaces are dangerous. But i think its a right way for thinking.

PS Mixing a lot of different changes in single multicommit PR isnt a good idea. Ty.
While applying those changes, noticed that `getStringWithLengthControl` is declared to throw some exceptions. Should `isLittleEndian` throw the internal exceptions as well instead of catching them?

SimpleDateFormat has not been deprecated, has it?
If there's a static SimpleDateFormat object we could use a ThreadLocal to restore thread safety.
Removing SimpleDateFormat and replacing it with newer APIs from a >500k LOC codebase is out of the question.

As requested previously by different committers in different PRs of yours, please discuss whatever you want to contribute in the mailing lists _before_ actually submitting them, to avoid wasting your time, and ours. 

Thanks!
@tbw777 That's the sort of reasons you're expected to discuss on the mailing list _before_ submitting a PR, not _after_ having submitted it.

> While applying those changes, noticed that `getStringWithLengthControl` is declared to throw some exceptions. Should `isLittleEndian` throw the internal exceptions as well instead of catching them?

I have mixed feelings here. The use sites don't give information about what went wrong, which would make it hard to debug. What would you think about this idea: let `isLittleEndian` throw all its exceptions, but add a multi catch for these before the finally-clause before 367, log errors there and rethrow. I would then not use `Exceptions#printStackTrace`, but a  `java.util.Logger`  on level INFO. `printStackTrace` creates useless message window.
@pepness thank you. In general looks good, but I left a few nitpicks inline.
@pepness wait, where did the commits go. now its only 3. Was that intended?
@mbien I was working on them. Fixed the suggestions that @matthiasblaesing suggest

> I was working on them. Fixed the suggestions that @matthiasblaesing suggest

@pepness ah, all good. I was just reviewing it and suddenly most of it was gone :)

just a general comment:
converting big blocks into lambdas basically loses the git blame history of the whole block. So I am not sure how useful that is all things considered. Maybe we shouldn't keep doing this in future. (Maybe consider reverting the largest candidates?)

Converting single char Strings into chars to use a different String method variant is also a stylistic change which has no runtime benefits anymore. Probably something we can skip over in future too.
added https://github.com/apache/netbeans/labels/Contribution%20welcome label. I suppose you didn't mean to select that you are planning on opening a PR for this?

This and more has also been supported for eons in Eclipse PDT. While warnings / errors you can make breakpoints yourself for (via the callback) - doing that for exceptions is impossible (so, there is no workaround). This is highly desirable for debugging as currently one can only set breakpoints in uncaught exception handler callback which is after stack unroll that destroys the error context - making breakpoints there fairly pointless.

So, i would like the "break on error" of the OP to be interpreted to also include the typical exception options.

> I looked through this and I believe this should be fine @neilcsmith-net. A lot of this are language identifier comparisons, file endings, SQL queries etc.

I think it looks fine too, although I haven't had time to look at all areas (like bugzilla) yet.

To be more explicit about what I was saying above, I think this should be evaluated as a bug fix.  I'm more interested in that aspect of it than any minor performance improvements.  And we should probably look for other uses of `to[U/L]Case()` that are not part of this but questionable, and should be using `Locale.ROOT` / `Locale.ENGLISH`.

> Whenever there is a comparison with a constant like "dev" it shouldn't matter if the cases are compared with a specific local or not.

That depends on what is being compared, and where the input string is from.  Consider -

```java
String input = "LIB";
boolean result = "lib".equals(input.toLowerCase());
```

The result might be true or false depending on [whether you're Turkish or not](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/String.html#toLowerCase())!
Pushing the exception lift change so it can be reviewed before squishing everything

Are you using NetBeans 16 or NetBeans 12.5?  If the latter, please update to a current version.  This is possibly a bug that was fixed.  Although the section of the log from `View / IDE log` would be useful.

Please also describe what you were doing when you experience the exception.  This is not enough information to proceed with.

Thanks!

Closing this issue as the main problem with implementation versions seems to be fixed.

The issue with these modules being rebuilt is still there, but the exact cause is still unknown and might not be worth the effort to fix unless it causes other issues.

I have to say that regular expressions is definitely not my strong point. So I'm not inclined to review this, even if it is easy. Especially since a change, even if it is considered "simple" could possibly introduce a change in behavior.

Again, if it were me, I would  say to myself: "Self, do we have a problem here or are we changing this just to be technically pure?"
at your discretion

Thanks for the report.  The Cupertino themes came in at the last minute tied to other changes in FlatLaf support.  Perhaps @DevCharly can comment whether this is an issue with the themes or how the custom properties are loaded / suggested?

> I used the default example accent ... which is a _very_ vibrant red color.

Yes, I wanted to make sure no-one missed the change! :laughing: I assume most people will set an accent colour of their choice.

From the examples in the description I don't see a real benefit. Replacing explicit character groups with their symbol does not help readability or at least it highly depends on the location. A quick look at the code changes supports this. From a review perspective this a nightmare and from a benefit perspective I don't see it.
This is invalid. `close` was added to `ExecutorService` in 19 and is just an alias for `shutdown`.
Thank you. As the unittests finally run cleanly through, lets get this in.

I asked `jackpot` for help and it answered (running the "Invoking Thread.stop()/suspend()/resume()" hint):

```
nbi/engine/src/org/netbeans/installer/downloader/dispatcher/impl/RoundRobinDispatcher.java:122:
nbi/engine/src/org/netbeans/installer/downloader/dispatcher/impl/RoundRobinDispatcher.java:168:
```

Well, I think the JDK is Java 16 and NetBeans is 12.5.

As @neilcsmith-net said, please use Apache NetBeans 16.

Well, yet another set of ambivalent changes.

Some of these could be valid, some of them indifferent and there are a few places, when it hurts the readability of the code a little.

Object creation in Java is cheap, really cheap. Doing these optimization on exception handlers, test code, simply does not worth.

Also there are a lot of places where the new code is more complex than the original one including a null check. that's just bad.
And very low value/noise ratio.

object reuse can be more expensive than allocating a new object. That is the whole point of a generational garbage collector: it is very good at cleaning short lived objects in chunks since it assumes most of them are short lived.

I am not in favor of blindly applying this everywhere since it is not obvious that it is of any benefit. If there are places identified which benefit from this - awesome. But lets not do this everywhere.

going to remove myself from the review list since I don't really want to review this unless it is reduces to a manageable size and proven that it is of any benefit.
